column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: When Internet Explorer opens a Web page, it places restrictions on what the page can do,
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: based on the page's Internet Explorer security zone. There are several possible security
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: its location. For example, pages that are located on the Internet will normally be in the
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: more restrictive Internet security zone. They might not be allowed to perform some
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: operations, such as accessing the local hard drive. Pages that are located on your corporate
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: network would normally be in the Intranet security zone, and have fewer restrictions.
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: ActiveX controls are Component Object Model (COM) objects and have unrestricted access
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: to users' computers. ActiveX controls can access the local file system and change the
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: registry settings of the operating system. If a malicious user repurposes an ActiveX control
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: to take over a user's computer, the effect could be significant.
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: To help improve security, ActiveX developers can mark controls as Safe For Initialization
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: (SFI), which means that the developer states that the controls are safe to open and run and
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: not capable of causing harm to any computers. If a control is not marked SFI, the control
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: could adversely affect a computer—or it's possible the developers did not test the control
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: in all situations and are not sure whether their control might be compromised at some
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf
CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: SFI controls run in safe mode, which limits their access to the computer. For example, a
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: worksheet control can both read and write files when it is in unsafe mode, but perhaps only
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: read from files when it is in safe mode. This functionality allows the control to be used in
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: very powerful ways when safety wasn't important, but the control would still be safe for
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf
CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: If a control is not marked as SFI, it is marked Unsafe For Initialization (UFI), which means
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: that it is capable of affecting a user's computer. If UFI ActiveX controls are loaded, they are
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf
CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: The Message Bar in Office applications is used to identify security issues, such as unsigned
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: macros or potentially unsafe add-ins. When such issues are detected, the application
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: disables the unsafe feature or content and displays the Message Bar at the top of the active
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: window. The Message Bar informs the users about the nature of the security issue and, in
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: some cases, provides the users with an option to enable the potentially unsafe feature or
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: Excel, PowerPoint, and Word can save graphic files in Portable Network Graphics (PNG)
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: format to improve the quality of the graphics when documents are saved as Web pages.
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: The PNG graphic file format (.png) is used for a wide range of graphics, from small images
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: (such as bullets and banners) to complex images (such as photographs), and can offer
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: better image fidelity and smaller file sizes than some other formats. However, PNG graphics
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: cannot be displayed by many earlier Web browsers, such as Microsoft Internet Explorer®
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf
CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: By default, Office applications do not save graphics in the PNG format. To change this
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: functionality, users can open the application's Options dialog box, click Advanced, click
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: Web Options, and then select the Allow PNG as a graphics format check box.
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: The Help Improve Proofing Tools feature collects data about use of the Proofing Tools, such
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: feature stops sending data to Microsoft and deletes the data collection file from the user's
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: account numbers, street addresses, and phone numbers are converted to zeroes when the
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: data is collected. Microsoft uses this information solely to improve the effectiveness of the
column2: CIS Microsoft Office 2016 Benchmark v1.1.0_ARCHIVE.pdf

column1: Office Proofing Tools, not to identify users.
